title: So helpful for keeping our teen safe!
text:
Really appreciate the filters. The bedtimes are great and it‚Äôs such peace of mind to be able to see what the kids are doing online. It is also really helpful as parents for keeping some form of control over devices and the floodgate that is the internet! Downsides...could have more options for allowing/disallowing sites and time limits. I wish every app on their phones would be shown on circle. Also, even when the internet is paused (usually because someone is grounded), messages still come through! They can‚Äôt respond, but it doesn‚Äôt exactly feel like the internet has been taken away! Also, I‚Äôve tried pausing other kids WiFi usage when they‚Äôve come over and it hasn‚Äôt don‚Äôt anything (once leading to an unpleasant incident because I thought they didn‚Äôt have any connectivity üòê). 
Still so much better than nothing, but lots of room for improvement!

title: Good tool for a virtual world
text:
This is a good tool to have in today‚Äôs virtual world where kids are now attending classes online via zoom and Google and other platforms and have access to computers and Internet connected devices 24/7. For working parents and those who can‚Äôt sit next to their kids 24/7, it‚Äôs nice to have a tool that allows one to filter content and limit access to non-educational sites such as games and video/television (especially during class time) and to enforce off-screen and bed times.  

The issues I have with this app arise when there is need for kids to access content that has been filtered or access a computer beyond an allowed time frame. It takes a little research and tinkering to figure out why a certain application or webpage is being blocked. For example, the app will notify if kids have exceeded screen time parameters, but it does not notify if content is being blocked because of bedtime or off time access parameters. (Sometimes more than one blocking parameter is causative.) The app will alert kids if content is being filtered, but it takes a real sleuth to figure out what filter parameter is being triggered. When I don‚Äôt have the time to play Sherlock Holmes and dig through history, it‚Äôs just easier to temporarily disable everything, which defeats the purpose of having this app.  

In conclusion, I wish the app would tell me specifically what and why something is being blocked and easily allow me to override the block as needed.

title: Latest Circle Bedtime Server Crash leaves Devices invisible.
text: We have had Circle for less than four months, and it was used in conjunction with our new Netgear routerÔøº model R7960 Tri-Band. The router is amazing and the Netgear NightHawk software for iOS is terrific.Ôøº However the Circle app has been touch and go ever since we originally set it up. Then things got incredibly worse with the latest Circle bedtime sever crash. All settings were backed up, but upon deleting the app (during troubleshooting phase) it takes the back up with it. Upon new install and setup, no devices can be seen.Ôøº Chat support was mediocre. Another Circle app reinstall with the Nighthawk software proved to be futile as well. Then the final straw was a fourth time set up saving one profile locked the screen and upon re-opening of Circle app started the process all over again from the beginning. Bottom line is that this particular software won‚Äôt even recognize any one of the 12 to 15 devices in our WiFi network even though all devices work seemlessly with the very robust Netgear WiFi router. The Circle concept and collaboration with Disney and Netgear is admirable. Our experience. Not so much. Subscription canceled today. :(

title: PARENTS DO NOT BUY
text: I‚Äôm a teenager and parents, I can tell you right now, your kid will HATE you for installing mycircle. Not only does it cause a lot of unnecessary problems between my mom and I (to the point where we had to see counseling), but it is also a HUGE invasion of privacy. The worst part about mycircle has got to be the history browsing one. It not only blocks websites but it RECORDS the ones you‚Äôve visited or have attempted to visit. This causes so much mistrust between the child and parent, to the point where I bought a second device and am constantly using VPN to block it out. As a teenager, we use our phones for everything and having our activity recorded is just not okay. Parents who don‚Äôt trust their kids don‚Äôt earn any respect from us, and it feels like they are insecure control-freaks. Instead, they could like talk to their kids or trust them to step up and tell you things. This just creates unhealthy habits and relationships. (Again, this is coming from a teenager- I understand using this for small children who are just starting to use the internet, but teenagers do not need it and it will only cause more problems. We will RESENT you guys for this, and remember it for our whole lives).

title: Mediocre at best
text:
I would like to be able to search for a device by Mac as this seems to be the simplest way to ID the item, instead of scrolling down a list selecting each item and checking for a matching Macby circle is implied to be part of what you get when you buy the $300 - $600 mesh routers. It is not. You get a 1 month free trial. Comcast offers this functionality with their XFi router. No additional charge.
2nd, there is no search functionality with in the app. So if you are an IT guy and have a lot of IoT devices, you get a notification that says a new device has connected to you network, tap it, it opens the app... that‚Äôs it just opens the app. Doesn‚Äôt take you the device to apply it to a profile, nothing. Instead you have to manually search through your full list of devices locate it and assign it. 
3rd, $50 a year come on guys I know companies need to have a steady income but this is our kids we are talking about here. And again at the cost of these devices these features should be included!

title: Circle is so much better than expected
text:
When I did some research on the ORBI modem/router, I had wasn‚Äôt aware of the type of interface that would be a part of it. After downloading Circle, I quickly learned that it offered (virtually) infinite possibilities. I‚Äôve had Circle for close to a year now and I absolutely love it.

 I can create profiles and add devices just for that person. My children have auto ‚ÄúOn/Off‚Äù Internet Access that I can control (literally) at my fingertips. The app will advise the person ‚Äúyour internet access is not available because your time has ended‚Äù. On the flip side, I can give ‚Äúrewards‚Äù and the access will stay on for whatever the time limit you provide (ex. Normal Off time is 8pm, Reward given until 9:30 pm).

There are so many options that it‚Äôs impossible to list them all. Just know that it‚Äôs a great app and you will NOT be disappointed.

title: Don‚Äôt install! Not a great choice..
text:
Hello to whoever is reading this review.. but I am a teenager and I find this frustrating and annoying to have screentime. I personally feel like Circle is a great device for screentime but not really for us teenagers since we want our own privacy. Screentime has not only made me and my parents have a miscommunication but provoked much fights since I don‚Äôt like to be recorded and moderated since it feels like my parents don‚Äôt trust me. It bothers my studies as well since screentime somehow blocks my school websites and makes my internet twice as slower than before which causes interruptions. Screentime adds more stress to me in my opinion since if I‚Äôm doing something really important then in a matter of seconds screentime is enabled it just angers me since I‚Äôm a student who receives a lot of homework plus screentime enabling at the wrong moments.. it‚Äôs just bothering. If any parent is reading thi review, instead of installing this app try talking with your teen about limiting technology addiction for it will help reduce problems and help you have a better bond with you and your child.

Sincerely,
Anonymous

title: Great!  No more being awakened at 2 am.
text: This service came ready to go on my Orbi wifi device, compatible with my Netgear router that is compatible with Xfinity internet service in Seattle area.  I‚Äôd never heard of the Circle app and thought it wouldn‚Äôt work.  However, I was sick of being awakened by my teenage son at 2am on a school night, while he was still playing video games and yelling profanities.  At first it was a little tricky figuring out which device was my son‚Äôs gaming laptop, but one I figured it out, I was golden and he was screwed.  I was able to set different bedtimes for school nights and weekends, and give him extra time when he asked so he could finish a homework assignment.  I was also able to instantly turn off internet to all his devices on an occasion when the situation warranted it.  Impressive way for my son to get more secure boundaries, and I think he is secretly proud of me for using a bit of a high tech method.

title: Premium service outage
text:
I have been using Circle they my Netgear Orbi router for about a year and a half. It‚Äôs great, but not infallible. My oldest just turned 18 and so we changed him to an ‚Äúadult‚Äù.  My 2nd is 14 and has bedtime at 10pm. So we were surprised to find her still playing minecraft after midnight.  Why?  

Disney Circle on Netgear is having an outage and has been since May 30th.  It‚Äôs June 5th now and a ‚Äúfix‚Äù is supposed to be rolled out tomorrow night, June 6th. 

Maybe this is due to two vendors having to share technology, maybe it‚Äôs because COVID19 has slowed everything, but if any company had a 6 day outage of service they should expect to lose customers.  It‚Äôs sadly unacceptable. They should have had a better QA and a better backout plan for whatever change caused this outage. I am sadly disappointed even with their communication (which has been mediocre but not non-existent). I hope they have plans to compensate their customers, who rely on this technology to protect their families.

title: Love It
text: This has been a game changer at our house - No more fighting (although my kids playfully tell their friends that it is awful LOL)!  The only limitation is that the history page makes almost no sense (it lists every ad on every page).  Otherwise it's very intuitive.  And while I don't think that is a substitute for collecting devices (ones they don't have, they can't use), it's a close second.  Super easy to use!  Just make sure to label each device as you are notified that it was added so that you don't have a ton of unknowns. I recommend this to friends constantly and it only gets a 4 instead of a 5 for offering some options that are not really up to speed (but also aren't really necessary to me - like history when I already have content filters on).  Great invention!!

title: Horrible app
text:
I have NETGEAR ORBi with Premium circle subscription. I had many troubles with this circle app on my iPhone in the past few months. The time limits were not working for several times for two ways. 

Sometimes it said a device has reached the time limit. But actually not because the app shows the device is only used for 10 mins. I disabled the time limit control, but the device still cannot connect to the internet. The screen shows ‚Äúthis device has reached its timelimit‚Äù. But there is no limit set! I have to delete the app, so my kids can take the online classes. 

Sometimes it is the other way. The time limit is not working. I set a two hours limit for my daughter, but she has been online for 5 hours already. 

Today, I have to reinstall the app again, reset all the profiles. What a waste of time. So I decided to call Circle. It again a waste of time. After talking to the 1st customer service, the call was dropped in the middle. So called again, the 2nd customer service said she is not trained for the circle product, transferred me to someone. After licensing to the music for 20 minutes, I decided to end the call. Have to delete the app, reinstall it, reset all the profiles. 

But now, it has been over 30 mins after the reinstallation of the app, the app couldn‚Äôt find any devices! So I guess I have to call them again.

title: Helpful partner but
text:
Initially I didn‚Äôt sign up for this application because it was separate from the router. But after power strike on my other router, I decided to give it a try and it was amazing. The ability to divide out all of my equipment was great. We‚Äôve been having someone hack our Internet from across the street and this was a great way to consolidate all the TVs all of the specific equipment in one profile and watch the activities and filter them out.

One of the problems with this application is if hackers name their stuff with a period in front of it or a name and then just a period with no extension the application does not allow the site to be blocked. I consider this a big oversight but the application is still very helpful in filtering.

title: Great tool for the family
text: We no longer have a giant pile of devices in our bedroom in the evenings. With Circle it‚Äôs easy to enforce bedtimes. Great content filters based on age group. We‚Äôd love to see a better History function that is easier to manage. It‚Äôs just a big data dump with time stamps. We discovered that our neighbor‚Äôs kids were still connecting to our WiFi from their own homes since Circle notifies you of any devices that join your network. It‚Äôs easy to deny those devices. No hassle when guests join. They are initially set to unfiltered and not bothered by any of our household WiFi security. Great tool. Hopefully, the monthly service price will keep the developer inspired to grow this product well into the future.

title: Currently useless against a tech savvy 11 year old
text:
The master pin rarely changes (I think only when a new admin device is added). So, if you child ever gets hold of your phone, he can note the master pin and add himself as an admin (or manager or whatever).

You do get a notification, but no ability to block  the new managing device. 
Once a device has been added as a manager it appears there is no way to deny it management rights. 

To make matters worse, you can set a pin in the app, but you only need to enter the pin on a cold start of the app, so if you change a permission and then let the child use your phone for something else, they are able to access the app and master pin without knowing the app pin. 

There are a few changes I would make to secure the app better: 

+ The app pin should be required every time you open the app, even if you just go to the Home Screen for a second. 

+ If there is one or more existing managers, at least one should have to approve any new mangers. 

+ The master pin should change more frequently. It should probably change every time you view it.

+ You should be able to kick out a manager. 

+ If we can‚Äôt get a pre-approval system for new managers, existing managers should be able to block new manager requests from specific devices or groups.   It seems crazy that a device with ‚Äúteen‚Äù permissions can become a manager.

title: Amazing
text: Exactly what I was looking for!  It‚Äôs integrated into our Netgear router and works seamlessly.  No more fighting with kids over devices, TVs, bedtimes, app limits, nothing.  Set it up and forget it!  They know what time things are cutting off and are prepared for it.  Again, no more fussing and asking, it just happens.  No more thought on our part, it‚Äôs just set to go on and off as needed.  You can always add reward time as needed too.  Just what I was looking for to control everything in the house by grouping devices to each child.  Been using over a month and it Lundy be easier.  Thanks!!

title: Wifi doesn‚Äôt come back at the scheduled time

title: This app ruined my life

title: Short changed
text: We have used circle in our home for almost two years. It took a while to get things set up and running for each profile. We had to tweak the rules several times but we eventually got things running smoothly. About a month ago, we had to replace our WiFi router. We shopped for one that was circle compatible. We thought this was a good idea. When everything got set up, all of the features that we knew and loved from circle we now a subscription based feature. It became nothing more than a brick to us at that point. We can no longer set bed times, time limits, or check history. All of our profiles have been deleted. Features that were free now cost $50 per year. We decided to use OpenDNS for our content filtering. It is more user friendly. We don‚Äôt have the ability to set time limits but that is something I will have to figure out later.

title: Great, when it works.
text:
I have been using Circle on Netgear for the past couple of weeks. When it works, it does exactly what it is intended to do. However, in order for the product to function, I must restart the router everyday, otherwise it will not not filter any website or enforce or even track device usage. Attempting to add or remove a device from a profile also will not work.  If a device connected to the network is not listed on the devices list, refreshing the list or opening and closing the app, restarting the phone, etc. does not help to add it.

After a restart of the router, Circle begins functioning again for about a day, after which it just stops responding, requiring another restart of the router. The Netgear RAX80 router works surprisingly well, but the Circle implementation leaves so much to be desired.

title: What this app did is SO WRONG.
text:
Like many other parents, I bought a Nighthawk router largely because it came with this software and it delivered some useful features to set time limits, set bedtimes, etc.

And while the app has always encouraged users to subscribe to a premium set of features, it never changed the basic set of features that were initially provided. Until now. 

Recently and without warning, most of the basic features of this app have been moved behind a ‚Äúpremium subscription‚Äù requirement. 

They are no longer honoring the advertising claims that were listed on the packaging of their very expensive router at the time of purchase. 

Think about what this means... 
* Every 5-star review praising this app is now deceiving.
* Even the screenshots are now deceptive, showing features that were once available to the purchasers of their router without subscription, that have now been removed unless you continue to pay. 
* Parents who purchased the Nighthawk router specifically in order to gain access to this type of control have had the rug pulled out from beneath them unless they continue to pay. 

It is like taking the control you once had, and holding it hostage. You want it back? Pay up.

title: Buggy and Invasive
text:
There are 2 major things wrong with this app and all of the circle apps in general. So, hear me out (from a teens perspective)
First, the concept of limiting screen time.
I didn't care much about screen time until my parents got this app. They restricted and paused things so much, that I felt controlled. I need screen time for things such as references for drawings. I also draw digitally, so restricting creativity isn‚Äôt helpful. Whenever I reference something, my anxiety says üìàüìàstonks ‚ú® because I feel like I‚Äôm wasting screen time. It‚Äôs a nightmare, especially if your child is a teen or tween. I understand limits for younger kids, but teenagers? That‚Äôs a bit much. I get good grades (all 90s and above) and am generally a good kid, so I don‚Äôt understand why I need these restrictions. Most of us (teens) are fine if parents leave us alone instead of bugging us for things. When I‚Äôm left alone, I do my work more responsibly than when my parents are bothering me about it every second. It also tracks websites and stuff. It‚Äôs invasive.

Anyways, don‚Äôt download it. It‚Äôs not going to work.

Second, it‚Äôs just really buggy. I got time when it said bedtime, sometimes I wasn‚Äôt online and it restricted my time. Not worth it.

title: Interrupts internet with Netgear routers
text:
Update: if I could lower this review based on developer response I would. They sent me to a standard troubleshooting guide that totally fails to acknowledge a problem on their end and instead suggests a whole bunch of other things besides Circle are the problem. 

Circle: get it together and own this problem. The internet is riddled with people reporting the same problem and getting no support from you or Netgear. I've disabled Circle and requested a refund on my subscription and I'm sure more Netgear Orbi customers will be doing the same. 

Beware before you buy. Google "Orbi Circle Interrupt" and review the comments. 

You will see that neither Netgear nor Circle will take responsibility for problems with this service. 

It caused periodic disconnect of all connected devices for months until I disabled it. If you work from home and spend time in web conferences or use VoIP audio you can imagine how disruptive this is. 

I asked Apple for a subscription refund which they denied. There's basically no accountability here for a product that does not work. 

If not for these fatal connection problems, the Circle product is actually quite good and would get 4 or 5 stars on its merits.

title: Had high hopes
text: So this service came stock with my Netgear Nighthawk R7000. Set up was easy, but that‚Äôs about all the good stuff that I‚Äôm going to say about this service. I signed up for the premium service plan, but the only thing that it worked well in doing was filtering the sites that I had blocked. None of the other features ever worked. The visited sites tab for each profile never populated and always indicated that no one was going to any sites which is impossible since they were clearly going to the sites right in front of me.  From day one, this service has caused nothing but issues with DNS resolution. It‚Äôs either the circle service or the router itself. Either way, I‚Äôm canceling the service and returning the router to the store.

title: Netgear compatibility issues
text:
I owned the Circle 1st generation for a while but needed to upgrade my WiFi router in order to improve range and speed. I purchased a ASUS router, just to learn it was not compatible with Circle. Now that all kids are homeschooling, I decided to purchase a new compatible router (NightHawk R8000P / AC 4000) and it has been a great disappointment.

After countless hours with NETGEAR support, the conclusion is that Circle app connectivity is broken. With iOS14, we couldn‚Äôt make it work at all. With iOS13, we were able to configure the devices but Circle is not doing its job of filtering content or pausing the internet for the devices, either individually or for the entire household. In other words, it is as if Circle wasn‚Äôt there.

I will be returning the NETGEAR router as The only purpose of the purchase was to have Circle.

title: Could use more options

title: Missing needed controls
text: Works really well for what it does. But you can‚Äôt see the usage of individual devices. It would be extremely helpful as a parent to know which devices my kids were on, and that seems like a total no-brainer. It would also make the process of identifying new devices about a hundred times easier. Right now every device that has ever connected to the WiFi in its entire history is included on one giant list. There‚Äôs no way to tell what‚Äôs currently connected. So dumb. Do any of the developers actually use this in their own homes?

title: Ended up throwing out Circle

Circle was okay when it worked, but any time it updated it‚Äôs firmware, or the router updated its firmware, the whole network would crash and I would have to unplug everything and restart it. At some point the physical device could not be powered down without breaking apart the plastic case and unplugging the wires to the battery.

Then the whole Circle/Eero non-compatibility issue came back with a vengeance and I had to either get rid of a $400 mesh network or a $100 Circle. I don‚Äôt care if it‚Äôs Eero‚Äôs fault or Circle‚Äôs fault, but when I can‚Äôt use my internet at all, something is going to end up in the garbage can. I‚Äôm tired of trying to make the Circle play nice.

title: Broken, discontinued
text: I have a paid 1 year subscription that isn‚Äôt up til March , but according to the website circle first gen was discontinued December 31st, I shouldn‚Äôt have been allowed to purchase a  new subscription after it was discontinued. title: Circle is terrible
text:
We set up Circle for parental controls with our new Orbi Router. Then all our problems began. With the kids and mom and dad all at home these days the internet and getting where you need to go is super important but circle would stop almost all moves on the internet. Even when we made devices as unmanaged ( what is the point then) things were still getting blocked. Calling support was no help as they would all tell me they are not circle trained and have to pass me off. Bottom line we shut off parental controls so the kids could at least do their classes and online school work. 

Thought it would be good with the Netgear and Disney name but I would stay away from this app on your phone and on your router.

title: Works very well
text:
Yes it takes time to setup.  This is not a set it and forget it type of service just like your kids aren‚Äôt all the same.  The internet is a big place and this thing can be adapted.
It is very customizable.  Not perfect.  It‚Äôs nice that there are so many profiles.
Mine is setup to give unknown devices almost no ability to go anywhere until I can figure out what it is.  This keeps the kids from bringing in new devices and getting into trouble. It also is an additional layer of security.
This thing can also be used to block trackers with a bit of effort.  History is certainly not exhaustive as the average website brings in content from many sources.
VPN blocking is also not exhaustive.  Those can be hard to spot.  One way is to visit websites and see what they are.
I like the various reviews from kids on here that hate it.  Says something about the product.

title: Blocked wrong device
text: I got unexpectedly dropped from a critical meeting today only to find out that a time limit I only impose on my son‚Äôs iPad was somehow counting my Internet time on my work computer, which had no time limit.  This isn‚Äôt the first time this has happened.  Ever since signing up for Circle and enabling parental controls through our Orbi router we‚Äôve had more network issues than before sometimes lasting for hours.  The app was easy to use and I rarely had issues with the app, but given these service issues today I ended my subscription and won‚Äôt be signing up again.  I‚Äôve measured that my internet is faster now too.

title: Used to be good, now slow and buggy
text:
Intolerably slow now with Roku, to the point that Roku often reports that the connection speed is too low to support streaming (and I have 60 Mbps).  Removing the Roku from Circle corrects the speed issue, but then I lose the parental controls.  Similar situation with other devices attached to Circle - their connections slow to a crawl.  Circle also now declares ‚Äúlooks like it‚Äôs past your bedtime‚Äù many hours before the actual setting.  Rebooting and resetting the Circle device does nothing.

Looks like we‚Äôre being bullied into buying the new Circle device, which now forces you to pay extra for features that were previously free.

Sorry, Circle.  I used to recommend you, but unless you get your act together I‚Äôm looking elsewhere,

title: Great but a little slow. 1st generation

title: Exactly What I Was Looking For
text:
Note: Circle is currently having a problem with their Premium features as noted on their site. In this day and age, experiencing a technical difficulty for several days is not acceptable. The should be offering refunds/credits to subscribers.

Prior to the premium service going down, this has been exactly what we were looking for. Reading the reviews from teenagers who are angry it exists is proof it works. We have a NetGear router that came with Circle integration.  Our speed has not been impacted in the slightest. Our oldest son is a gamer and he does not experience any lag. We ran speed tests between our current and old router, and even with Circle, the new router is actually faster (routers were fairly similar, we upgraded for Circle). We discussed the limits we were imposing with our kids when we set it up (bedtimes, age appropriate content filter, etc.). The only times our kids even know we have circle is when they are doing something that is against our family rules. If they are following the rules, it doesn‚Äôt have anything to block. When I was a teenager, I thought I knew it all too and I didn‚Äôt agree with the rules my parents had for me, but as an adult, I understand. If we don‚Äôt fight for our kids‚Äô purity and equip them to chose to be self-controlled, this world will continue to devour their minds and creativity. In my opinion, Circle as surveillance is too far, but Circle is great for establishing and enforcing boundaries for screen time.

title: Check for app updates if it stops working. Circle won‚Äôt notify you.
text:
This app is a very useful free utility which I use peripheral to my Netgear RAX200. The product is set to be integrated with a smartphone and this app. Setup is easy with set by step graphic prompts and only takes minutes to set up eith several machines, enabling the ability to manage sets of internet connected device and even monitor the website usage of certain sets on age based contents. You can monitor / filter types of websites, control internet traffic to certain machines, and even set up time limits (which i still have try the last one.)

I am docking 2 stars because tracking and website filtering functions on the app abruptly stopped working. I went to their website and followed the initial steps to solve the problem and it didnt help - rebooting the router, reinstalling the software, etc. This didnt help. I contacted Circle‚Äôs customer service, and they said they couldnt help and directed me to contact Netgear. Netgear is meticulous in th help they give, but reaching them is hard and getting a case number in their systems is not quick. After 2 days of trial an error, it was determined that the app was not compatible with the 0.98 firmware update that I was initally required to install upon setup of my router. (Beware this update, RAX200 customers.) While this issue resta more with Netgear, Circle should have known this too and notified customers automatically to keep them informed.

So that‚Äôs why I docked 1 star. The second star I docked because of an experience that came up few days ago. I was having the same issue with website monitoring functionality going away. The app was acting up again, and to be clear, it was not tracking website history of machines I had setup to be observed and block online gaming from (on school days.) I went back to Circle‚Äôs  website to see if there was anything else I could do and did what i could at the time, delete and reinstall the app as advised. That was yesterday, and i had to wait this morning to follow up and reboot my router (because it was too busy on our WiFi for school, work, etc.) Upon rebooting, and around 15 or so minutes, the Circle App was working again. Becaue this second error happened, I questioned the stability of the app and looked for more information on the website. I had found that the problems I had overlapped with the timesc that 2 updates happened for the app for bug fixes. That is frustrsting to hear and I find should‚Äôve been disclosed by the company. I feel Circle‚Äôs support system is lacking for the 1st Generation version of the app. Monitor updates when your app stops working. Thanks for reading.

title: Ok hear me out
text:
I am a high school student, so if you want to take my information about this app as biased then go ahead and keep scrolling. But for those who want to see a formal review of this concept in the perspective of the child, keep reading. 

The idea of circle is understandable, as all parents should be concerned about what their children are doing online and should protect them from the horrible aspects that the internet can provide. But the fact that parents are spending their money on a network device that blocks out house WiFi (and cellular service) which they‚Äôre ALSO paying for is considered acceptable and convenient? I don‚Äôt see how this logically connects to every necessary part of the situation. 
I don‚Äôt see how I‚Äôll be able to contact my parents during a serious emergency while on the go if my internet is paused.
I don‚Äôt see how I‚Äôll be able to complete all my online school work if my parents have an ‚Äúall categories‚Äù limit set to 3 hours(I‚Äôve tried talking to them about that, they just give me a 15 minute reward over and over which wastes all of our time. Lots of parents are passive-aggressive like mine). 
I don‚Äôt see how the whole mechanism is going to work, if I‚Äôm spending my HARD EARNED money on cellular data, and they‚Äôre just gonna spend THEIR money to block it out. 
Yeah, the whole situation just wasn‚Äôt completely thought out by the developers. It is a brilliant idea to help protect children, but the whole thing just isn‚Äôt very convenient for the whole party. 
Also, circle just shouldn‚Äôt be necessary for kids older than the age of 16, since they‚Äôll be a legal adult in just <2 years and they‚Äôll have to figure out how to manage their own screen time by themselves eventually.

Parents, if you‚Äôre planning on getting yourself this network-killing device, please take a moment to look at yourself, how your relationship with your children will be, and if it‚Äôs going to be beneficial for EVERY part of their life(including online school!). Please be aware that your children will feel punished, and will cause trust issues between you guys. 
If your children have some screen time problems right now, I would deeply imply having a friendly conversation with them about it first before surprising them with a restriction right out of the blue. It‚Äôs like trying to quit smoking cold-turkey(not like they‚Äôre actually smoking, just take it as a simile). As a teenager who has experience with parents who ghostly put restrictions on me whenever they want without telling me, it‚Äôs a bit traumatizing. 
But, if you‚Äôre a good parent and your kids know it, and putting restrictions for them is necessary, and all your limits you provide them are fully thought out, 
OR, 
your children are just utterly psychotic and won‚Äôt get their eyes off a screen for less than 10 hours a day, then go ahead and get Circle.

But please, be careful. I‚Äôm saying this for the sake of the kids :c

title: A good device
text: I am a parent of a teenager who spends entirely too much time on her devices.  I've tried other apps like kidslox (which was good but not great.  Circle is really easy to install and can give time limits to each app and or each category.  It is a nice tool for parents to use.  The MyCircle app also gives kids an app in which to monitor themselves.  I have only 2 complaints.  1) the monthly subscription of $5 beyond the $90 for the device and 2) for devices like the computer it only monitors the computer as a whole not each account on the computer.  So if a parent wants to use the computer they would be using the 'allotted' time given to the teenager.  True you can just change it to 'uncategorized' then change it back but that is not a smooth transition.  There are several areas which the company promises to improve but for my needs it works really well.  I do recommend this device/app for any parent that takes an active role in their child's online life.  This is in no way a parental replacement.  Don't listen to the naysayers of this device/app.  It is well worth the price although I would like to see a lower per month rate.

title: Good..... but.....
text:
Been using this service for over a year and I really like it.   That said, two major issues:
1). As soon  as your kid gets a Chromebook from school you loose 100% of any control this product provides.  Schools often use a VPN to ensure control over safe browsing.  When this happens not only can do you lose control over app content (which I understand based on how VPNs work) but you also lose the ability to control screen time.  The kids run out of time on the phone or tablet and then just use the Chromebook since it can‚Äôt be managed.   Unlimited time. 

2). The kids are using all sorts off apps that aren‚Äôt identified in the filter.  When you go to ‚ÄúUsage‚Äù you‚Äôll find the bulk of the time is in the ‚Äúuncategorized‚Äù section with only an IP address to identify it.  A good example is Amino which is a community app with some really questionable content.  I‚Äôm sure most folks don‚Äôt know how to run a WHOIS command to track this down.  And even then it‚Äôs often uninformative.  Suggest Circle hires a couple folks to look at the top uncategorized sites and capture the content so we know the app that is associated to the IP address.  Many of these addresses now go to a company that builds/operates apps for their clients.   As such much of the information you would want from the app isn‚Äôt there.  As a parent you are left blind on the bulk of internet usage.    I hope the Product Manager for the app can prioritize something like this in the near term backlog.

title: Don‚Äôt understand the complaints
text: IF you know ANYTHING about a computer at all or WiFi this app is very simple. I don‚Äôt understand all the complaints people are complaining about. You locate devices by the MAC address or on the genie app IF you have Netgear. If your not sure what your blocking or not blocking simply go into the sights and check the age appropriate materials ect. This is not a baby sitter and children should not be left in a room running computers at free will anyway. We always check in on what our son is doing and when he‚Äôs done he is completely switched off until the next time. Video games are allowed to connect rarely and we monitor those as well. We don‚Äôt allow children free run on the internet in our home. And the TV is setup requiring passwords on unrated programs. Parents take responsibility and quit looking for a short cut to babysit your children. Get involved and know what‚Äôs going on great App and 5 stars to NetGear for including it in your routers.

title: Very helpful parenting tool!
text:
This has helped our parenting skills & to keep firm limits with them! The task of parenting in the digital age is daunting.
So many things that can be harmful for them & it hard to constantly be up to date on everything. With phones, home computers, tablets, tv‚Äôs & video game consoles all having access to the internet. It‚Äôs impossible to constantly monitor what they are on especially as they get older. Also at the age where we have more kids hanging out or sleepover with phone. It helps me know when in my house there is some level of protection from them viewing things they aren‚Äôt ready for. 
We struggled with them following our time limits for video games. Which has now ended! 
I may be a mean parent, but I‚Äôve read the research & I don‚Äôt allow mine on social media of any kind right now. There is plenty of rime for that when their brains are ready. Social Media is blocked! 
The only reason I didn‚Äôt give it a 5 star is you can‚Äôt assign a device to more than one person, which I understand  would be a challenge. And it would be helpful if it had more detail about what they have looked at etc. in history.

title: Not Helpful
text: First off, in my opinion this app doesn‚Äôt help kids grow or let me parent. If you just limit amounts of WiFi time, kids can still use their screens. Often, apps have an option to download content, allowing them to view it offline. Second, just limiting their time doesn‚Äôt teach them anything. My daughter just feels a need to not waste her time, making her go on more than she would naturally. I found a more effective way to teach my children life skills. When I feel they should take a break then I give them ideas of what to do, this helps them learn to be entertained in a different way. There should also be a partner app for the kids so they can monitor how much time they have and can use it wisely. Third, my kids often have schoolwork online, and who wants to waste WiFi time for fun stuff on homework. They often try to do it really quickly, skipping on quality. If i allow them to do their homework later they sometimes have already run out of time. The filter and tracking is the only thing i don‚Äôt hate, besides the fact that it is very glitchy and wrong. In the end this app isn‚Äôt to help you parent it lets you avoid parenting all together. A second partner app would be beneficial to allow kids to know how much time they have left. However, i will be uninstalling.

title: Great solution for us
text:
Circle has been a great solution for our family. We've tried software that is so inconvenient for me to check email or read a blog post that it's infuriating to use the internet at all, so we just disable the filter. Not good. Circle and the ability to personalize devices filter levels has been super! Installation is easy and customer service has been great when mom can't figure something out.  üòúThe app itself is reliable and user friendly.  

 We have multiple devices of different makes and the filtering is pretty effective on all devices. We are with Circle now and I hope we can continue to be in the future but increased filtering efficacy, coverage when kids take devices out of our wi-fi network, and the ability to disable particular apps and block offline apps should be high priorities in updates.  If Circle could throw some more of the weight of Disney behind its technology and become a one stop shop for parental controls this could be a big win for parents...and kids. For now, it's just a solid tool which hopefully will keep getting better as the technology grows.

title: Doesn't seem to work all that well
text: Doesn't seem to work all that well. I got circle not knowing that it may not work well with our cable router. But once I learned that, I read about the workaround which was disabling one of the two thingies (technical term) our cable router uses. So I logged into our router and turned off access to the 5 thingie but left the 2.4 thingie. Whelp, circle still doesn't work consistently. Ive tried googling things that shouldn't come up and they will. On top of all of that, the major bummer for us is that circle doesn't stop apps that don't use the internet or that only need the Internet occasionally. We allow a lot of off internet apps and circle can do nothing to restrict those. Time limits won't apply for those either. It's my fault for not realizing that circle wouldn't work for that purpose, But still a bummer. It would be nice if there was something that could totally lock down my kids iPads and other gadgets instead of just turning off the Internet. Instead I've just decided we need to be technology free during the week. So circle hasn't really helped us at all. But it had made me realize that we have been using too much technology and I need to step up my parenting game.

title: Excellent concept but...
text: I love the ability to do all that you can with this program. For the price, I believe that the consumer should have more tedious control. I have the switches set in place and I still don‚Äôt feel in control. I would like the ability to actually view which websites and content is being viewed. I hate that I have to completely remove a device from being manned to be able to use it. I want to be able to view what my child sees from the app and block or unblock it. It feels like all or nothing with this system. Then, I can‚Äôt tell which device is which sometimes. There needs to be a better way to tell which device I‚Äôm setting up. Then, there are certain parts of sites that I‚Äôm ok with but not others. I need feature and subject blocking abilities. There are so many possibilities with this program that are untouched. When improvements are made, I would be happy to change my view. Also, if I‚Äôm paying more than $100 for the Disney circle box, the mobile service should be included. I shouldn‚Äôt have to pay more on an already expensive item. I think it‚Äôs ridiculous that I do.

title: App works 50% of the time

I have 2 kids and use circle to monitor and limit their usage. However with one, the app always reset from ‚ÄúTeen‚Äù to ‚ÄúNone‚Äù every day so I have to keep checking and switching it back to Teen so that‚Äôs it monitored with restrictions. title: Are these fake bad reviews or what?
text: I don‚Äôt get it, this thing is awesome. Super easy to setup. If you notice any internet dropout issues just restart your modem, router, and the Circle once or twice and it all seems to workout. I haven‚Äôt had issues since I did that on day 2 (which the instructions said to do on day 1 but I didn‚Äôt). I love being able to easily limit stuff like fortnite and roblox and manage it all separately. And it‚Äôs so easy to add time, pause WiFi etc. I have a separate zone setup for all my kids Alexa‚Äôs to turn off at night which is great. I‚Äôm a huge fan for all this under $100. I haven‚Äôt looked into the paid subscription part, but my kids don‚Äôt have devices on cellular. If that‚Äôs what people are complaining about, that should be a separate review imo. Get this thing, especially if you have kids under 10 that you want to easily manage. One day they get older I‚Äôm sure I will have to make adjustments.

title: Love this app - my kids hate it
text:
Love this app! No idea why the negative reviews.  Reading some of them made me hesitate, however I thought I could easily test it out.  I am not any kind of computer whiz and I found it very easy to understand - after following the instructions.  

My 2 teenage boys hate it (and their friends who stay over)!   I now have full control over when they can access the WiFi network in my house - control over each device and further control over which apps and websites.  I love that I get to limit the screen time and can do that for each individual app or website.    My personal favorite is bedtime - no more surfing late at night. I can also give time rewards for extra chores or extra ‚Äúsweetness‚Äù as my wife likes to say. 

This is the first app review I have ever given - reflecting how strongly I feel about Circle.   This internet access control is more than I ever dreamed of.

title: Brilliant so far
text: I was worried our kids would have figured out how to bypass this by now. 15&17 yrs old. But, after  2 weeks they haven‚Äôt yet. It‚Äôs  hilarious. Their reaction when it shuts off for the first few days and the ‚Äúbargaining‚Äùfor just a few more minutes. With just a touch of the button you can set it and forget it. I used to block their Mac addresses and change the password but that took a lot of time and confusion. Circle  does slow down their internet for certain things, but to combat that, you can move their device to ‚Äúunmanaged‚Äù as a reward . And once they start messing up they get switched back to ‚Äúmanaged‚Äù and have to put up with ‚Äúcrappy internet‚Äù. Our youngest is always trying to figure out how to get his device off the crappy internet LOLWhat a great way to teach children boundaries and responsibility without physically or emotionally harming them. Love it.

title: Nor more fights about internet restrictions with the kids!
text:
This device and the app are both great tools in the battle against all the junk on the internet. Easy setup, even easier management with the app. The design is very intuitive and easy to understand. This app takes a complicated thing like monitoring you wifi network and the layers and layers of technology and simplifies it into a beautifully designed interface. 

With this device and app a parent can do all the things you want to do with your wifi network. Assign devices to people in your household, create bedtimes, limits for apps and websites, filter based on age groupings, then tweak them based on what each person needs. Leave devices (like my ooma phone) unmanaged. Allow (or deny) guest access, and during dinner, pause the internet with one tap. 

I can change restrictions on the fly, if the kid needs to stay up late to finish some homework, couple of taps and i move the bedtime back. 

Support has been fantastic, with fast response times, and clear help when needed, although honestly there wasn‚Äôt much help needed. The thing just plain works. It does its job (and more) quietly and elegantly. I only manage it as much as I want to. I can tweak the snot out of it, or just leave it be. I want to set it and forget it, until I need it, and it just plain works.

title: Love this product
text: We use this at home and use the other app associated with this device, mycircle go. It does everything it's supposed to but there is a couple of tech issues with this app. The app will randomly restart as if you are setting it up new and requires you to make a new profile before you can see the current profiles already on the app. Then the other issue is with the circle go portion. It will say the device is deactivated when it is just connecting to a different wifi. Twice in the week we have had this the parent app says the vpn is disabled on the child device but when I check it is enabled. And only restarting the home router has fixed this issue. Please fix this and it will be perfect! These issues are minor compared to how well it works to filter,pause, set time restrictions.

title: Works great most of the time
text: For my needs circle works effectively most of the time. It is kinda buggy sometimes, especially on one of my kids‚Äô phones with the circle go installed, but overall this has helped a ton with policing the internet overuse in my home. I really don‚Äôt care that sometimes it cuts people off early or overestimates the amount of time they‚Äôve been doing certain things. I‚Äôd rather they‚Äôre almost never on their devices anyway. Circle go is kinda iffy and makes a lot of things not work on the network, which is kind of annoying and to be honest I‚Äôm about to get rid of it, but I understand that it in it‚Äôs infancy and they have to work within the restraints of the network and how to apps connect. Anyway, overall we are happy with it and my life has improved since installing it in my home. A lot of the complaints in the reviews are covered and explained well in the circle help and troubleshooting.

title: Easy to use...works great!
text: I struggled with built-in parental controls on a few different mesh routers and none of them were easy to use and frankly, none of them worked.  I figured I'd give Circle a try and I'm so glad I did. I have complete control over my network, who can/can't be on my network, what they can see, how long they can be on it and can even see what websites they've been on.  I have several kids, all with iPads and friends with iPads and other devices so having this control and visibility is tremendous.  It was very simple to connect to my network, easy to set up profiles for each family member and assign devices and set up internet usage and bed times.  If you have kids, no matter what age, Circle is a MUST if you want to manage usage and have insight into what your kids are doing online.

title: Not able to get support
text: Normally I wouldn't write a bad review and I would love to change this review, but I can not find support for an issue -- big one.  My iPhone circle app "lost" it's connection with our circle.  I go to reconnect it and my circle is not showing a wireless network address.  In the meantime, my son's iPhone is paused.  I have no way to get on to manage household devises now.  I have looked and looked through support q&a for help on this.  There is no support to call when you issues.  As I said earlier, really hate to write a bad review.  I think it's a great product/idea, but they need a better way of helping people who are having issues. Adding to this:  shut down my network so I powered it off.  I took the Go app off my kids phones.  I could not take the pause off their phones that I had not put on in the first place.  I am trying to cancel my subscription now, and do not have a clear place to go to do that. I probably would have continued to try the product except I could not get help.  This concerns me for the future if I stayed with this product.

title: Promising, but falls short
text:
I had a lot of hope for this product, especially with the involvement of Disney.  Unfortunately it all fell short of great expectations...very short.

Set-up was a pain.  For some reason this ‚ÄúPIN‚Äù they send to you didn‚Äôt work on my iPad and I couldn‚Äôt even get my iPhone to the screen to ask for it.

After a few resets of everything, I managed to get it working.  All in all, it took 30 minutes to just troubleshoot and get it working.  That didn‚Äôt include registration, etc.

Next, setting-up and using the app.  Once again ... fell short of even a good experience.  It is mediocre, at best.   The functionality is limited and everything is all about subscriptions.  Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I‚Äôm willing to pay for these, but not when they are still in the early days, like this app is.  Granted, I know this product should be well beyond its early days!   If I recall, it launched 1 1/2 years ago.   

Last, the fact that in this day and age, an app like this doesn‚Äôt work on an iPad in Portrait AND Landscape mode is inexcusable.   I can understand some other types of apps, but this is basic.   There‚Äôs nothing in this app that would make it complicated.   I would know, I build apps for a living.  

Sorry Circle & Disney, this product is still far from where it should be.  You could have apps on iOS to better inform users of their time up, you could have better screens.  There‚Äôs no ‚ÄúDisney Magic‚Äù in this!

title: LOVE this device and app
text: My husband and I LOVE this device and app. We have 3 kids and many devices in our house. We have profiles setup for each kid and even one for their shared items (computer, xbox). It has been amazing. Kids have limits now and network connection shuts off for them at a certain time. So all kids are differnt based on ages. It also allows us to block other app distractions when they need to be studying or doing projects. And I love the Reward option to be able to give them extra time when earned. You can make changes instantly for which apps they can use or if some apps needed to be limited. And the best (but most frustrating for my son) is the "Pause" button when he's been told he needs to leave and can't tear himself away. No more yelling....my the parents....in our house!

title: Just what we needed!
text: Before the circle I felt like our kids‚Äô internet use was out of control. Our kids are required to have laptops for junior high and high school. They were on them constantly! They are also supposed to turn in their electronics a half hour before ‚Äúlights out‚Äù, and that was never happening. We were always chasing them down and reminding them. We saw the circle in action at a friend‚Äôs house and got one for ourselves. It has been wonderful! They magically remember to turn in their electronics on time (because the internet is set to turn off at a certain time) they are following the limits about how much total time they‚Äôre on them, and I can easily and quickly see where they‚Äôre spending their time. It‚Äôs just what we needed!

title: Best money I ever spent on hardware
text: I considered building my own content management appliance for the home network (I build and maintain large-scale Internet systems for a living), but after estimating the time and comparing Circle‚Äôs feature set, I bought a Circle appliance (and later, a Circle Go subscription) and never looked back. The reviewers who are saying it‚Äôs easily hacked either don‚Äôt know how to secure a network, or perhaps the Netgear-branded version operates differently. If you have a stand-alone Circle device, and a Circle Go subscription, your kids will *not* be able to bypass it without your knowledge (the notifications are timely and accurate). Feature set and UI are good (although not always flawless; I‚Äôd give 2-3 stars for inconsistent behavior). Overall, a great buy (have had one since before the Disney partnership, when they were still in startup mode).

title: Why has Disney betrayed us??
text: Y‚Äôknow, I love Disney. Their movies are great, their merchandise is so pathetically useless that you just HAVE to buy it, and it‚Äôs got a couple of great theme parks. But the whole thing about Disney being super fun and especially for kids is just not a thing anymore.. because of Circle. I‚Äôm the gaming-meme-internet freak in the family, and my sister is too. We hate it. As long as ‚Äòhating it‚Äô still means that you have an impulsive feeling to walk over, beat it, kill it, whack the snot out of it, and other things that are worse. Disney was definitely putting itself at an all-time low creating this ‚Äúamazing‚Äù app. Now that I think about it, my dad spent ninety-nine dollars on this app and other features just to kick us from the Internet. I can‚Äôt play Roblox, my sister doesn‚Äôt have social media, and we‚Äôre stuck on a screen that says, ‚ÄúLooks like it‚Äôs past your BedTime‚Äù if we open our devices after seven. Disney sure could fix this up, erase this app, and be fun again. But it sure looks they won‚Äôt.

title: This app does not work as promised...beware
text: I used Circle on subscription successfully for a very few months, and then...my premium features just disappeared.  After many tech support e-mails there has been no resolution. They say they‚Äôre working on it, and the months roll by.  For our family, it‚Äôs the premium features which make it worthwhile. We need data, not just an on/off switch, because we are trying to build our kids‚Äô digital awareness, and yes, we do combine active parenting and family discussion with the app control.   They (Circle/Disney) have been apparently happy to keep taking my $4.99 per month, however, in spite of not providing the service I‚Äôm paying for at all. I‚Äôve tried to get refunds of the monthly fee and have sometimes succeeded. The ONLY reason we purchased the Netgear router was for this service. Very unhappy with the result and am gong to try again t cancel. I advise anyone needing a good set of supportive parental controls to not waste your money here - look elsewhere.

title: Was partially working and then nothing.
text: We were pretty excited to get Circle. We first started noticing a problem when we couldn‚Äôt get allowed websites and videos to load on our devices. And then we realized the history feature wasn‚Äôt working. I called tech-support and after an hour, instead of getting history to work, I slid backward ended the phone call with lost profiles (which had required an extensive search to identify and rename all our devices based on MAC address) because the backup didn‚Äôt load and without the ability to even connect to the Circle app! The representative was nice enough, but admitted it needed to go to a senior technician. When I got the email from the senior technician two days later, I followed those trouble shooting instructions exactly with no luck. I‚Äôve now got another set of instructions to follow. Great idea Disney, but your execution is flawed. How about we allow really well-designed apps like VidAngel a chance to filter content ‚Äî instead of blocking and suing them?

title: This is a terrible idea
text: If i could give this zero stars I would. I‚Äôm 18 years old and on a medical leave of absence from college for my mental health and this has enabled my mother to completely start dictating my life. It‚Äôs ridiculous. She has said time and time again that i‚Äôm an adult now and it‚Äôs time to act like one yet she‚Äôs using this app to treat me like a child. She‚Äôs installed this without my knowledge or permission and I believe that violates my privacy. You shouldn‚Äôt just be able to restrict someone‚Äôs device without their knowledge. it‚Äôs unethical. especially because i‚Äôm a legal adult and i was not even informed by my device that it was actively recording my usage. Which is just downright illegal. It‚Äôs recording my usage and my data without my permission or knowledge. I did not agree to have my data processed. My mother allowed it, but i‚Äôm a legal adult and she doesn‚Äôt have legal permission to speak on my behalf anymore. Maybe you should make sure your app is legally safe before putting it up in the app store. This is atrocious.

title: Great app to help manage usage
text: They key word there is ‚Äúhelp‚Äù. After I first downloaded the app, I went an entire day waiting for it to patent my children for me. To my surprise, I am still the one responsible for parenting my children. I was hoping I could bail out early with this app and not have to teach my children responsibility and the importance of following rules. Nope, my dang son brought home his laptop from school and KABAAMM, I was stuck having to manitou his internet on the school laptop. Well, actually, he‚Äôs an 11 year old so I simply stated his school laptop is to used at the kitchen table where he can be monitored and no pleasure surfing was allowed on the school laptop. Holy crap, it actually worked. Now, because of this app, I can go back to not parenting my children. Whew, crisis adverted.

title: Exactly what we needed
text: Setup was really fast and hasn't affected internet speed detectably, even for streaming and large uploads. I love the customizable control for each family member and knowing what I need to know right from my phone, including the domain names (not individual page URLs) of sites the kids are using. We bought it because we weren't allowed to install parental controls on my son's school-issued laptop. Circle works at the network level, with no installation on the kid's devices. NB: Make sure that all wifi networks with reasonable signal strength are password protected, so that kids can't circumvent Circle by switching networks. We had to ask our neighbor to put a password on his guest network, which he was happy to do. I'm so thankful for this product.

title: Highly Recommend
text: Circle has been a great addition in monitoring our kids internet usage.  As we all know a wide open internet can lead kids down some undesirable paths.  Circle allows us to set parameters and monitor where they‚Äôre going and what they‚Äôre doing online.  We‚Äôve set some broad perimeters and can narrow that as needed.  The kids have been okay with the set up, so it‚Äôs been going well.  One of the greatest benefits is parental peace of mind.  Studies show internet addition is a real thing, especially for the developing teenage brain.  We want to help our kids navigate the world especially the wild wild world of the internet.  Circle allows us to do this without clamping down the reins to hard.  I would highly recommend Circle.

title: So far we love it
text: We bought the circle device after Christmas last month at the advice from a friend. Set up was easy, the odd names change to more recognizable device names after they are turned on. It has worked flawlessly in control and monitoring our 11 year old. I love the pause and bedtime features and customizable age categories. She is not broken into the system as others have said nor has it caused problems with our WiFi. Five stars from this parent for all three of my kids of different ages. You can even block explicit access in adult accounts while leaving everything else alone. We have discovered it is also blocking ads on our 11 year olds phone. Awesome.

title: Circle helps manage all my kiddos devices!!
text: We are a foster family and we have kids from all kinds of situations. It‚Äôs been a constant struggle to stay on top of their internet usage, both time wise and context! With circle I am able to pause each individual child/teens internet until they can get homework or a chore finished, but I can also reward them with extra time! They love the positive reinforcement they get just from getting their bed made or making a good grade on a test! Not only can I control internet usage but it gives me a breakdown of how much time they spend on each type of internet platform, and allows me to ‚Äònot allow‚Äô certain apps. Circle is a life saver for this family!!!

title: Terrible app, pretty much useless
text: Setup was fine. Was able to setup profiles and devices. But once done, app is useless. Keep saying a new devices joined the network but when you go to device list none of the newly discovered devices show up! The device list needs a LOT of work. Devices appear out of the blue, miss labeled, etc... So with the device list on the app not working I figured I would try to go to the webpage on a computer and it tells you there is no circle devices on the network, even when the app works and sees it AND even after entering the IP of the circle device directly. No wonder it‚Äôs so cheap... been using the Ethernet connection or the wireless, I also made the changes requested to support my Velop network and turned off express routing... no dice! :(. Hope they can fix the app! This is NOT a new device so they should have the app polished and working at this point...

title: Love it...when it works
text: BUT, any time you reset your router or the power goes out, the app stops recognizing your subscription...which means your paying for nothing.  And there is absolutely NO customer service to speak of. This is really doing a disservice to the Disney name and their reputation.  I spent HOURS looking through endless articles to find an answer, got nowhere, then found a phone number (not online by the way- it was in an email from the first time I had this problem), waited for over 45 minutes and nobody answered. My phone finally died so I still have not found an answer or received a response from the not so fabulous email support. I‚Äôm beyond frustrated. I truly love the app when it works, but there is no excuse for not being able to get help and for taking days to reply to paying customers. I will look for another service that is more responsive. :(

title: Amazing from Day 1
text: I think the bulk of the bad reviews are either from people who are computer illiterate or from teenagers who are upset that their parents are filtering their Wifi. I‚Äôve had Circle for about 2 years now and never have I had a problem. One of my favorite features is how it alerts you if a new device joins your network and will automatically filter it to the ‚ÄúHome‚Äù profile. That way, my kids (or their friends) can‚Äôt sneak a device into our home WiFi without us knowing. As stated by many other people, Circle is. It a babysitter and does not take the place of teaching your kids how to be responsible it it a very valuable tool to help control what comes into your home.

title: Just what we‚Äôre looking for
text:
First off, as I told my kids when we got this device: it is not a substitute for parenting. It‚Äôs a tool to stop them from accidentally stumbling on adult content and to warn them about spending too much time on their devices. 

I still have parental controls on my children‚Äôs devices so they can‚Äôt download whatever they feel like and I talk with them as well. Again, this is not a substitute for parenting. 

As far as the device goes, we‚Äôve had it for about a month and so far it‚Äôs working great. It was easy to set up and all of the features have been working. We also bought the circle go subscription and it‚Äôs working great as well.

title: Disappointing
text: So disappointed in this product with Disney's name. The product keeps touting limiting "screen time" but it can only monitor and control apps and content that uses the internet. In other words anything that doesn't use the internet is a free for all: Minecraft (offline gaming, or any other game that doesn't require internet), movies and videos stored on the device etc. When I buy a device that says "limit screen time" I want exactly that. I want to be able to set a time limit for individual users or at least devices so that when the limit is reached, the device is essentially bricked for that user. A lot of other filters and granular controls would be nice and somewhat expected, but the previous is an absolute must. I will be returning it until something better comes along or my kids are older and filtering online content is more of a must.

title: A Good Start
text: Having the ability to restrict WiFi access and cellular on mobile devices (for an extra monthly fee is a good start). But key capabilities are missing: 1) On shares devices (TVs, iPads) and services with multiple users (eg Netflix) need to distinguish between users; 2) Need control over device access as well, so when children run out of network access they don‚Äôt just spend the rest of the day on games or apps that an be used without connectivity; all apps - or better all apps except those a parent leaves accessible - should not be able to be started. For example, I should be able to have all my child‚Äôs apps inaccessible after a time limit, but should be able to leave phone, text, and specific apps for homework (eg google docs) or for listening to music accessible with specific limits independent of overall time limit, or indefinitely.

title: Not tracking time limits well
text: I‚Äôve had the circle for over a year and only have had problems occasionally, but lately you husband and I notice that our children are online longer than usual. Today, I‚Äôm just in the house when the kids went online. They played fornite on Xbox.  After 1 hr, I check the app for the usage time and it says they are on 10 min. Each of my kids have their own profile and each of them says inaccurate time than what the usage displays. This has been an issue we‚Äôve been noticing for the last couple of months. It renders the circle useless.  What is going on? When I check ‚Äúhistory‚Äù it also doesn‚Äôt display correctly. There is a chunk of time missing, when the kids have actually been on the entire time. Before now it‚Äôs been a great filter so far, and very useful with 4 kids of varying ages, now it‚Äôs useless.

title: Why are mysterious ghost devices showing in the device list?
text:
Update:  so it seems that the Orbi router keeps a cache off every single device that has ever connected to it. Even devices that might have connected months and months ago show up in the list. The Circle app picks of this same list and shows it as devices to be managed.  I guess this is OK but it is confusing. Probably something to add to directions.   
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî////‚Äî‚Äî/
Great concept but very buggy and lagging software.  Not sure if I would trust yet.  It shows I have 27 devices on my network when I really have only 10.  There are devices showing up even with names of people I don‚Äôt even know (Like ‚ÄòJoe‚Äôs iPad‚Äô)  This is on netgear nerwork locked to the teeth (the router admin shows only what I know I have) - crazy,

title: Not worth it
text: No need for this app it doesn‚Äôt do much and what it does do isn‚Äôt positive or helpful. As a kid with this app who has got the bedtime on their phone I think this app only  stresses out the people using it. I am not writing to be bitter or mean because you took away my games but instead to explain why it is that this app makes bedtimes hard and it shouldn‚Äôt. This app tells you that bedtime is near about 30 minutes before and sometimes certain electronics shut off early which is hard to deal with before bed. It also allows certain things like if you download Netflix episodes it will allow you to watch them and on Pinterest you can do certain things. Any apps that don‚Äôt need WiFi you can use even after bedtime. This app  just does things and allows things that make it stressful and a much better thing to do would be to take your child‚Äôs phone away or put on restrictions in settings.

title: No customer help at all
text: In general the app works well. Initially we used the trial and things ran fine. Then we upgraded to the $4.99 per month subscription.  One issue is if we stopped a device on the circle app and tried to turn it back on, it takes about 10 minutes, even though the app says it‚Äôs connected. Then suddenly one morning, the app stopped working. The app says ‚Äúunable to find circle‚Äù. After a 2 hour search for answers, turns out there is no way to contact any customer service assistance what so ever. Just an endless ‚Äúcircle‚Äù of completely unhelpful information. It‚Äôs ridiculous that we are paying money for an app that just suddenly stops working and no info anywhere about what to do to fix it. Tried rebooting the internet, reloading the app itself, even tried setting the app up all over again - nothing works.

title: Parenting Life Changer
text: So my kids have their own devices, which all have parental controls on them, but one thing I have struggled with is how many hours they are on and seeing exactly which sites they are spending their online time in. This gives me time online, sites they visit and for how long and allows me to pause it. I no longer have to yell for them to come down and eat, just hit pause and the kids come downstairs. Prior to this I had catch my 10 year old on his iPad at bed time or he would wake up early to go play, now the devices are disabled until 10am and they go off by 7pm. The one warning is this works best if everyone owns their own device.

title: Ineffective
text:
I really wanted this app to work - it‚Äôs a great attempt - but the realities of how devices leverage the Internet makes it impossible to properly measure usage and enforce time limits. If we just use it for game systems, it seems to accurately track usage. It reports a whole bunch of IP addresses and hostnames, but the app seems smart enough to realize that many of them are concurrent, and the one that matters (epicgames a.k.a the devil Fortnite) seems to define the critical path and triggers the usage limit as intended.

But as soon as we have the system try to govern iPads or iPhones, it goes to hell. Those devices seem to constantly be reaching out to a ton of hostnames and IP addresses in the background, which completely messes up the usage and time limits. I don‚Äôt have the time or patience to manually manage all of those things, and even if I did, it would require constant upkeep

title: Works like no other
text: This product works great for our family.  I see other reviews of low stars and most are config issues.   I found thiis to be very easy to install, it has not conflicted with any apps or services and its working great for our 11 yr old daughter.  She's learning to be conscious of her time online, respect (albeit grudginly) the time limits and works for 'extra time'.  Eases my worries and concerns.  I'm in the cybersecurity business and I've looked at other services, this one is simple, basic and practical.  I could easily get a firewall, content filter, etc. and make it 'enterprise', but this is my home and I just want to ensure my child is safe with responsible 'screen time'.

title: Excellent product with great visibility...
text: I am not sure what is up with some of these reviews, but I suspect a lot of them are kids who just hate accountability and they are trying to scare users away, same with the Circle Go. However Disney has a great product here, is it perfect? Nothing is. However they have worked hard to give parents close trips over their home and their kids devices. I recommend this product regularly as I help parents learn about protecting their home and family. One time price, control over your home, visibility into your kids lives so you can talk about accountability and responsible device use... priceless.

title: $4.99 a month?
text:
I can not say this rating is fair, but thought informing others would be useful.  I have a Netgear router that I just updated and they offered ‚ÄúCircle with Disney‚Äù.  As with most parents, I would like some more help with my kids screen time and this looked to be it.  

Long story short (ish) they offer two ways to use it.  Basic, and Premium.  The basic offers features already offered on most routers like monitoring traffic, or pausing the internet (there was a 3rd option in basic but I don‚Äôt recall what it was, just that it was already offered on my router). The premium offers all the good stuff ... for $4.99 a month. I wasn‚Äôt looking for another money drain so I deleted the app and asked to have my accnt deleted. 

It might be a great app, just not worth $4.99 to me.

title: It works for what I need.
text: I started using this app and it works fine for what I need. I use the free version because It is too expensive to afford $4.99 a month not saying that it does not worth but for me it is too much. I can have control of my internet and the devices connected to my network. In the past all my kids friends used to come to connect to my network to the point that one time I checked that there were about 45 devices connected and my internet was super slow. Now I blocked lots of content they can access to so little by little all those extra devices don‚Äôt connect to my network because is boring.

title: Must Have for a family. Great Customer Service!!
text: I bought Circle probably over a year ago and it worked great until about 2 months ago. After an update they wanted to start charging me a subscription for some features that I previously had for free. So I gave them a negative review...within hours someone reached out to me and showed me how to go back to how it was before. I also was starting to have issues with it not filtering properly so I asked about that as well. They promptly responded and showed me how to fix that as well. So I am removing the negative review and leaving a positive one because of the exceptional customer service.

title: Please add a search feature in device list!!
text:
After a year my device list is quite long. When I need to find a specific device I can‚Äôt easily find it. Device names don‚Äôt change when you rename your phone so I have many duplicate devices. I‚Äôm forced to search by MAC address which requires me to click on every device in the list until I find the right one to assign it to a family member. Either add a search in the device list or simply show MAC address in the device list so it‚Äôs easier. 

It would also be nice to see a list of currently active or recently active devices. Many of the devices in the list are now old.  

The Circle has served us well for years. Thanks.

title: Good app
text: I like this app because it helps block websites and turn off the internet when I want devices to be off. We have a big family so this is just making it easier for me to know that my kids are getting a break from screen time. Something that was a problem was that my daughter was still getting on the chat for Gmail and I had to block her email entirely to make sure she wasn‚Äôt on their. I like how you can add specific websites that you want blocked or allowed and also the time limits for each device since I have some older kids and some younger. Overall, it has been a pretty good app.

title: Empowering for parents
text:
